content.description: Without a doubt, climbing Mother Neature is one of the neatest things you can do. Breaking the ice can be hard, but it’s nice and secure once you’re established in the wide crack. Once inside, birth your way through the horizontal wide crack splitting the roof. How neat is that.
content.protection: Pads & heat. A TR can be built roughly 10 feet or so behind.
content.location: Center of the wash, look for the grey wide crack, just left of the curving hand crack.

content.description: Another suggested route name was “Why on God’s Green Earth???” but I like to think that if you harness the power of the Rainbow Sandals then you will float right up this thing like there’s a magic carpet beneath you. Worth it? Probably not. Crux is doing the classic South Mountain top out.
content.protection: Pads, etc. Rainbow Sandals. A TR can be built by using gear far behind.
content.location: A few steps left from the sandy wash center. Look for the overhung incipient micro crack with jugs on both sides. Maybe best identified by the irregular boulders that lie below.

content.description: Follow the striking curving crack into the cosmos then birth yourself out of the butt crack roof.
content.protection: Pads, friends, EPT. This problem can be led with hand size gear or a TR can be built roughly 10 feet or so behind (bring directionals also).
content.location: Center right of the wash. Obvious curving crack just right of the center wide crack.

content.description: A decent little wall with some tall problems, bad landings and great crack climbs. This wall is best for those testing their boy scout traditional top rope building skills or those just chuffing around the local boulder field. A couple of climbs exist here with more waiting to be plucked on the left side of the wall. TR anchors can be built using gear in the varied cracks roughly 10 feet or so behind the wall.
